On Jan 4, 2012, at 2:44 PM, Jorn Wildt wrote:

> Forms are nice if you acc=
ept the overhead on the client when requiring it to understand all the elem=
ents of a form.

What exactly is 'the overhead'?

> 
> But, Jan, how does t=
his fit into your view of (almost?) always(?) using domain specific media-t=
ypes? Or is this a different scenario? Or something else ... ?

I do not re=
fer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that instructs th=
e user agent what data to include in the submission (including fixed (aka '=
hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of the specific=
 media type(s) I define.

> 
> > An example would be the current price of a=
n item. Instead of constructing an order and including a remembered price, =
the current price can be right in the form for the client to review and the=
n put into the submission request.
> 
> Just remember to add some kind of d=
igital signature to the data, such that clients cannot alter the price once=
 it is given to it.

Why's that? The server can easily check whether the su=
bmitted price is a price it accepts. The server need not carelessly send th=
e order to the backend without a check. But, ok, yes - a check-key could be=
 used to verify the data came from a form actually created by the server.

=
Jan
